The Air Liaison Officer, Bahrain, Memorandum, Reference your telegram Ho,A 437 dated 25th June 1942 to Air Headquarters about wireless observation posts on the Qatar Coast, 2, On July 3rd I saw the Shaikh of Oatar at Riyan and ex plained to him what was wanted. He gave his verbal consent to v the establishment of R,A,F, wireless observation posts in his territory and agreed to provide any guards required, 3, Before the posts are actually established will you please give me a few days 1 notice so that I can inform the Shaikh of the number of guards required, of the amount of their pay, and of and the date on which^the place where they should report for duty. At my Interview with the Shaikh he was not in a mood in which such details could have been discussed with advantage. The Shaikh at first stipulated that the men in these posts should wear Arab dress. Obviously he was frightened that men in Service uniform might attract hostile attack. I explained that it was not possible to comply with this stipulation, and that, in any case, details of dress could not be distinguished from the air. The Shaikh did not press the matter further at the time, but I mention it now as he may raise it again. Political Agent, Bahrain. c^h Vf. (t-f. physicalDescription.extent: The contents of the file are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest items at the front to the latest at the rear.

Foliation: The foliation sequence starts on the front cover and finishes on the back cover; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and can be found in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. Circled index numbers in red crayon can also be found throughout the volume. Foliation anomalies: 1a and 1b.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence relating to a request from the RAF to the Political Agent in Bahrain, to install wireless observation posts [WOUs] on the north-east coast of the Qatar peninsula. Permission was sought from and given by the Shaikh of Qatar, and assistance in the set-up of the posts provided by representatives of Petroleum Concessions Limited. A report on a visit made by Flight-Lieutenant A. Johnson to Kuwait, Bahrain and Qatar (where a survey of possible sites for wireless observation posts was undertaken), dated 27 June 1942, is included in the file (folios 6-7).
